string-array.name: def_rec_0
string-array.item: Focus 100% on fundamentals: grip, stance, and sight alignment. Ignore the clock.
Your only goal is to hit the target, no matter how long it takes. Do not rush.
Practice dry-firing to feel a smooth trigger press without anticipating the shot.
A jerky trigger pull is the most common error. Squeeze the trigger slowly and smoothly.

string-array.name: def_rec_1
string-array.item: Accuracy is the priority. Forget the clock. Master the fundamentals of your grip and stance.
Your precision is very low. Focus on "dot drills"—hitting a small dot from a short distance.
Ensure your sight picture is perfect *before* you even think about pressing the trigger.
Slow down. A perfect shot that takes 5 seconds is better than a miss that takes 2.

string-array.name: def_rec_2
string-array.item: You are shooting far too fast. SLOW DOWN. Speed is useless without accuracy.
You must force yourself to see a clear sight picture *before* every single shot.
Your speed is uncontrolled. Go back to slow, deliberate shots to build correct muscle memory.
Practice "call your shot" drills: say where the shot will hit *before* you check the target.

string-array.name: def_rec_3
string-array.item: Your speed is ahead of your skill. Focus on precision first, then speed.
You are rushing your shots. Confirm your sight alignment for every single shot. Don\'t rush.
A good shot you *almost* make is a complete miss. Slow down to guarantee the hit.
Practice shooting at different, slower cadences to find your balance of speed and control.

string-array.name: def_rec_4
string-array.item: Your precision needs work. Focus on a steady grip and a smooth, continuous trigger press.
Your speed is very slow, which is okay for now. Master accuracy first.
Practice "grouping" shots. Try to get all shots within a 3-inch circle, ignoring time.
Are you flinching? Try mixing dummy rounds (snap caps) with live rounds to diagnose a flinch.

string-array.name: def_rec_5
string-array.item: You are inconsistent. Focus on making every shot identical, from grip to follow-through.
Practice "trigger reset" drills. After a slow shot, release the trigger only to the reset point, then press again.
Your fundamentals are shaky. Do a 10-point check of your grip, stance, and sight picture before you fire.
Don\'t try to fix speed and accuracy at the same time. Fix your accuracy, then add speed.

string-array.name: def_rec_6
string-array.item: You are sacrificing accuracy for speed. You must slow down to make your hits count.
Your speed is impressive, but uncontrolled. Practice "throttle control"—shoot fast on easy targets and slow on hard ones.
You are likely snatching the trigger. Practice a smooth, continuous trigger press, even when moving fast.
Force yourself to confirm your sights are aligned for every shot. "You can\'t miss fast enough to win."

string-array.name: def_rec_7
string-array.item: Your accuracy is inconsistent. Focus on seeing what you need to see (a clear sight picture) for every shot.
Your speed is average, but your precision is holding you back. Refine your trigger control.
Try "target transition" drills, but focus on *pausing* at each target to confirm the hit before firing.
A smooth draw and presentation can save time without sacrificing accuracy. Practice this part of your drill.

string-array.name: def_rec_8
string-array.item: Your accuracy is good! You have a solid foundation, but you are far too slow.
You are being too cautious. Start trusting your sight picture and press the trigger sooner.
Practice with a "par time". Set a timer and try to get all your (good) shots in before it beeps.
Work on the "in-between" actions: your draw, your target transitions, and your reloads. This is where you save time.

string-array.name: def_rec_9
string-array.item: Your precision is reliable. It\'s time to start pushing your speed.
Don\'t just shoot faster; be more efficient. Eliminate wasted movement in your draw or presentation.
Use a shot timer to measure your "split times" (time between shots) and try to reduce them by 0.05 seconds.
You\'re ready for more dynamic drills. Try shooting while moving or engaging multiple targets.

string-array.name: def_rec_10
string-array.item: This is excellent performance. Your speed and accuracy are well-matched.
To get to the "Optimal" level, focus on micro-adjustments. Is your first-shot-on-target *perfect*?
Practice on more difficult targets (smaller, farther) to see if your precision holds up at this speed.
Add complexity: shoot from awkward positions (kneeling, prone) or after physical exertion.

string-array.name: def_rec_11
string-array.item: You are a competent and reliable shooter. This is a great baseline.
The next step is "throttle control": learning to shoot at *exactly* the speed a target requires (no faster, no slower).
Introduce pressure. Compete against a timer or a friend to improve performance under stress.
Work on your "visual processing." How fast can you see the target, see your sights, and make the decision to shoot?

string-array.name: def_rec_12
string-array.item: Your precision is perfect. You have mastered the fundamentals, but you are extremely slow.
You are too cautious and obsessed with a "perfect" sight picture. You *must* push your speed.
Trust your sights. The moment you see a "good enough" sight picture, press the trigger.
Use a shot timer relentlessly. Work to shave tenths of a second off your draw and your split times.

string-array.name: def_rec_13
string-array.item: Your accuracy is excellent. Do not let it make you complacent or slow.
Your foundation is solid. Now it\'s time to build speed on top of it. Trust your skills.
Practice accelerating *between* shots (fast trigger reset and sight re-acquisition).
Introduce movement. Practice entering and exiting positions quickly while maintaining your accuracy.

string-array.name: def_rec_14
string-array.item: This is peak performance. Your goal now is 100% consistency.
Can you maintain this performance under stress, when tired, or in bad weather?
Introduce more complex problems: multiple targets at varying distances, and "no-shoot" targets.
Teach someone else. Explaining your process will reinforce your own mastery of the skills.

string-array.name: def_rec_15
string-array.item: Excellent work! You are both accurate and efficient. This is the goal.
To reach the "Elite" speed tier, you must optimize your visual processing and split times.
Practice "calling your shots" at speed. This confirms you are seeing your sights for every shot.
Find your failure point. Push your speed until your accuracy *just* starts to drop, then work at that boundary.
